video.title: Adam Savage Wishes the News Would Cover This Subject

content.summary:
News misses some crucial context that would help people think more clearly. Tiny margins in massive elections aren’t meaningful numbers without error bars; with millions of ballots, recounts will vary every time, so a reported lead of thirty-five votes or twenty-eight votes is statistically indistinguishable from zero. Another example of misplaced focus is shark attacks: with fewer than about five incidents globally per year among billions of swimmers, the sample size is so small it can’t support sweeping conclusions.

First, let’s look at how statistical literacy could improve election coverage. Horse-race updates on microscopic leads treat integers as exact, but in real counting, especially at scale, human and process variability make small differences evaporate on recount. The responsible frame would present margins with uncertainty and treat razor-thin spreads as provisional, not decisive signals.

Another blind spot is how the press frames labor “shortages.” Headlines about pilot shortages or teacher shortages often skip the core economic reality: there’s plenty of trained talent, but pay and conditions don’t match the expertise, risk, and difficulty of the work. Raise compensation to fair levels and the “shortage” disappears, because it was never about supply—it was about price. Commercial pilot pay, in particular, can be startlingly low relative to the responsibility carried, and that mismatch drives attrition and bottlenecks. A better coverage template would ask first: are wages and working conditions competitive for the skills required?

In niche culture, one passion that deserves a louder spotlight is cosplay. It’s a sophisticated craft ecosystem that blends design, fabrication, performance, and community. Giving it more mainstream attention helps legitimize the work and gives makers easier ways to explain their art to skeptical relatives who only see costumes, not the engineering behind them.

Authenticity in the original movie-prop market is another area ripe for real reporting. There’s plenty of promotional hype around “hero props,” but very little independent, professional investigation into provenance. A healthy market needs rigorous, adversarial vetting—chain of custody, materials analysis, and consistent standards—to protect both collectors and history.

Shifting gears, there’s a fun practical thread here for treasure hunters and makers. For finding deals, Facebook Marketplace is excellent, Craigslist remains a reliable weekend scan, and upscale consignment platforms like The RealReal and 1stDibs can surface specialty pieces at very different price tiers. San Francisco happens to be great for garage sales, and checking listings weekly pays off, especially when you’re after unusual shop fixtures or shelving that never show up when you need them.

If you want the thrift-store endorphin rush without driving block to block, head to antique malls—big spaces where many sellers consign under one roof. They’re hit-or-miss in the best way: some booths overprice, others underprice, and patience gets rewarded. Tools are a sweet spot because fewer people seem to be actively collecting them; old wooden apple crates, brace drills, and hand saws can be surprisingly affordable and genuinely useful. The ideal outing is often browsing a ton of fascinating pieces and leaving with nothing—you get the inspiration without the clutter.

So what’s the bottom line? Better journalism would pair statistics with uncertainty, challenge labor-shortage narratives with pay and conditions, and put real scrutiny on prop authenticity. Meanwhile, celebrate cosplay as a serious craft, and if you’re hunting for materials or inspiration, check Marketplace and Craigslist weekly, then lose yourself in an antique mall where undervalued tools and clever storage often hide in plain sight.
